pain_points_original.title: Stringent Government Security & Data Sovereignty
pain_points_original.description: As a government entity, AGS must adhere to strict, non-negotiable security protocols, including IRAP PROTECTED certification and Australian data sovereignty, which significantly limits viable AI vendors.

pain_points_original.title: Inefficient and Manual Legal Workflows
pain_points_original.description: Current legal practice workflows are manually intensive, hindering lawyer productivity. AGS seeks AI to augment high-volume tasks like drafting, summarising, and discovery to improve overall efficiency.

pain_points_original.title: Lack of Integration with Core Legal Systems
pain_points_original.description: Any new AI solution must deeply integrate with core systems (iManage, Elite 3E, MS Office) to avoid creating data silos and disrupting workflows, which would negate potential productivity gains.

pain_points_original.title: Need for Trustworthy and Explainable AI Outputs
pain_points_original.description: For a government legal authority, AI outputs must be transparent, defensible, and explainable. The "black box" nature of some AI presents a significant legal and reputational risk that must be mitigated.

pain_points_original.title: Risk of Adopting Obsolete AI Technology
pain_points_original.description: AGS is concerned with investing in basic generative AI that will quickly become outdated. They seek a future-proof platform, showing interest in advanced 'agentic AI' for autonomous, multi-step tasks.
